Sheet1.Question: Your organisation is moving to an Agile way of work. Your project team are strongly opposed to using Agile as they have been burned using iterations, when executives used the team velocity to try and force the team to work faster instead of keeping a sustainable pace. What will you do next?
Sheet1.A: Add extra resources to your team to deliver faster and avoid executives getting involved.
Sheet1.B: Proceed with a predictive development approach, and deal with the consequences later.
Sheet1.C: Ask your team to work with Agile, velocity and iterations despite their hesitations.
Sheet1.D: Suggest the team uses flow-based scheduling, with a Kanban board for visual work.
Sheet1.Reason: Kanban is one of the largest parts of Agile approaches, aside from other major parts such as Lean, XP and Scrum. A flow-based scheduling approach does not use sprints, lifecycles or velocity but optimises deliveries based on resource capacity, and minimises waste such as context-switching and hand- offs.

Sheet1.Question: There are certain core practices that are common amongst all the frameworks, and used within any team that calls themselves Agile. below is NOT a core Agile practice?
Sheet1.B: Collaborative User Story Creation between the business, custom and testers
Sheet1.C: Demonstrations and Reviews of the features developed
Sheet1.D: Autocratic Leadership, to ensure the work gets done
Sheet1.Reason: The preferred style of leadership in an Agile team is Servant Leadership. Autocratic leadership typically is a one person affair, while servant leadership builds psychological safety for the whole team to engage and contribute. All other items listed are Agile core practices.

Sheet1.Question: Agile has certain core practices that are used within any team working in an Agile way. Which of the following is NOT a core practice of Agile?
Sheet1.A: The whole team approach, where any person needed is brought into the project team.
Sheet1.B: Early and frequent feedback, to ensure a common understanding of the product.
Sheet1.C: Daily stand-ups, to report on progress and raise blockers.
Sheet1.D: Reporting to executives, to ensure they are happy with your project.
Sheet1.Reason: While reporting to executives has its place when running a project, in Agile it would rather be done by including them in other Agile core practices, such as demonstrations or reviews of the product, showing the product burndown chart in the team area, and the backlog of work. All other items are Agile core practices.

Sheet1.Question: You are working on a project as an Agile project manager. You look at the product backlog and ensure several features, or minimum viable products (MVPs) can be scheduled for delivery throughout the duration of the project. Why is this a good idea?
Sheet1.A: To show executives that progress is being made by the development team
Sheet1.B: To keep the project duration short
Sheet1.C: To enable users to test the product for quality, and give feedback
Sheet1.D: To enable the business to get value quickly, as features are delivered
Sheet1.Reason: Minimum Viable Products are usable features in their own right that are delivered incrementally. This allows for business value to be gained more quickly, while gathering feedback on the use of these features.

Sheet1.Question: You are running an Agile project and meet with the team for the next sprint planning meeting. What will you do next?
Sheet1.A: Negotiate the scope and costs of the project with the project sponsor.
Sheet1.B: Walk through three questions with the team-what did I do yesterday? what will I do today? Is anything blocking me?
Sheet1.C: The dev team demonstrates the working feature to the product owner, who marks it as complete.
Sheet1.D: The product owner shares the updated backlog, and the team discusses it to ensure a shared understanding.
Sheet1.Reason: The product owner should share the updated backlog items and ensure the entire team has a good understanding of how to move forward.

Sheet1.Question: What is the primary goal of Agile project management?,
Sheet1.B: Following a strict plan
Sheet1.Reason: Agile focuses on delivering value incrementally and responding to customer feedback.

Sheet1.Question: What is a Scrum Master responsible for?
Sheet1.B: Shielding the team from external interruptions
Sheet1.Reason: Scrum Masters protect the team from external distractions to maintain focus.

Sheet1.Question: What does WIP stand for in Kanban
Sheet1.B: Weekly Improvement Plan
Sheet1.Reason: WIP limit refers to the maximum work items allowed in progress at a time.

Sheet1.Question: What is a User Story in Agile?
Sheet1.B: A high-level project overview
Sheet1.C: A short, simple description of a feature from an end user perspective,
Sheet1.Reason: User Stories describe features from the user's perspective in a simple format.

Sheet1.Question: How often does the Scrum team hold a Sprint Review?
Sheet1.B: Weekly
Sheet1.D: At the end of each sprint
Sheet1.Reason: The Sprint Review is held at the end of each sprint to inspect the increment and adapt the product backlog.

Sheet1.Question: What is the purpose of a Retrospective in Agile?
Sheet1.B: To inspect and adapt the team process
Sheet1.Reason: Retrospectives focus on inspecting and adapting the team's process for continuous improvement.

Sheet1.Question: What is the recommended size for a Scrum Development Team?
Sheet1.B: Five to Nine
Sheet1.Reason: Scrum recommends a Development Team size of 5-9 members for better collaboration and communication

Sheet1.Question: What is the main advantage of using burn-down charts in Agile?
Sheet1.A: To track team members' daily work
Sheet1.B: To monitor project risks
Sheet1.C: To visualize progress towards completing the sprint work
Sheet1.Reason: Burn-down charts help visualize and track progress towards completing the planned work in a sprint.

Sheet1.Question: What is the main purpose of a Product Backlog?
Sheet1.A: To store all ideas and requirements for the product
Sheet1.B: To assign tasks to team members
Sheet1.C: To track daily progress of the team
Sheet1.Reason: The Product Backlog is a dynamic list that contains all ideas and requirements for the product.

Sheet1.Question: In Agile, what does the term "Velocity" refer to?,
Sheet1.A: The speed of the team's daily tasks
Sheet1.B: The capacity of the team in a sprint
Sheet1.C: The time it takes to complete a project
Sheet1.D: The number of story points completed in a sprint
Sheet1.Reason: Velocity measures the team's capacity in story points completed during a sprint.

Sheet1.Question: What is a common practice in Extreme Programming (XP)?,
Sheet1.B: Infrequent communication with customers
Sheet1.Reason: XP encourages frequent pair programming as a collaborative development practice.

Sheet1.Question: How does Agile handle changes in requirements?
Sheet1.A: Changes are not allowed once the project starts
Sheet1.B: Changes are discouraged but can be accepted with approval
Sheet1.C: Embraces changes in requirements throughout the project
Sheet1.D: Changes are only allowed in the planning phase
Sheet1.Reason: Agile embraces changes in requirements throughout the project to adapt to customer needs.

Sheet1.Question: What is the purpose of the Definition of Done in Scrum?,
Sheet1.A: To define the team's daily tasks
Sheet1.B: To track team progress in a sprint
Sheet1.C: To set the standard for when work is complete
Sheet1.D: To assign responsibilities to team members
Sheet1.Reason: The Definition of Done sets the standard for when a product increment is considered complete.

Sheet1.Question: In Scrum, who is responsible for removing impediments?
Sheet1.B: Team Product Owner
Sheet1.Reason: The Scrum Master is responsible for removing impediments to the Development Team's progress.

Sheet1.Question: What is the purpose of a Sprint Goal in Scrum?,
Sheet1.A: To list all tasks for the sprint
Sheet1.B: To provide a high-level objective for the sprint
Sheet1.D: To assign priorities to user stories
Sheet1.Reason: A Sprint Goal provides a high-level objective that the Development Team works towards during the sprint.

Sheet1.Question: What is the primary focus of Lean software development
Sheet1.B: Minimizing waste and optimizing efficiency,
Sheet1.Reason: Lean software development focuses on minimizing waste and optimizing efficiency in the development process.

Sheet1.Question: What is the significance of the Daily Scrum
Sheet1.B: To inspect progress towards the sprint goal and adapt the plan
Sheet1.D: To assign tasks for the day,
Sheet1.Reason: The Daily Scrum is for inspecting progress and adapting the plan within the current sprint.

Sheet1.Question: How does Agile promote collaboration within a team?,
Sheet1.A: By discouraging communication among team members
Sheet1.B: By having strict hierarchies and roles
Sheet1.Reason: Agile promotes collaboration by fostering open communication and close collaboration within the team.

Sheet1.Question: In Scrum, what is the purpose of the Sprint Backlog?,
Sheet1.A: To assign tasks for the day
Sheet1.B: To track team progress in a sprint
Sheet1.D: To list all user stories for the sprint
Sheet1.Reason: ,The Sprint Backlog is for assigning tasks for the current sprint.

Sheet1.Question: What does the term "Definition of Ready" represent in Scrum?
Sheet1.B: The standard for when a user story is ready to be pulled into a sprint
Sheet1.Reason: The Definition of Ready sets the standard for when a user story is ready to be pulled into a sprint.

Sheet1.Question: How does Agile promote customer collaboration?,
Sheet1.B: By encouraging customer feedback throughout the project
Sheet1.C: By assigning a dedicated customer team
Sheet1.D: By keeping customers isolated from the team
Sheet1.Reason: Agile promotes customer collaboration by encouraging feedback and involvement throughout the project.

Sheet1.Question: What is the primary focus of the Scrum of Scrums meeting?
Sheet1.A: To discuss individual team member's performance
Sheet1.B: To address technical debt
Sheet1.C: To inspect progress and dependencies across multiple teams
Sheet1.Reason: The Scrum of Scrums meeting is for inspecting progress and dependencies across multiple Scrum teams.

Sheet1.Question: How does Agile prioritize features in the product backlog?
Sheet1.B: By customer priorities and value
Sheet1.Reason: Agile prioritizes features in the product backlog based on customer priorities and the value each feature adds to the product.

Sheet1.Question: How does Agile respond to changes in customer requirements?
Sheet1.A: ,By avoiding changes after the project starts
Sheet1.B: By strictly following the initial project plan
Sheet1.C: By welcoming and adapting to changes throughout the project
Sheet1.Reason: Agile welcomes and adapts to changes in customer requirements throughout the project.
